blog.name: theladymeera
blog.title: I'm So Salty I'm a Pickle
blog.description:
Daenerys was my first fave and she will be my last.

Danielle, US. Meera is the frog queen of my heart but I post more about my dragon queen Dany. Trying to be a happy person against the will of all these nihilistic men.

This is my ASOIAF/GOT side blog. My main is a-mountain-girl, my booklr is readingaway.

summary: Please, do rant away! There's so few Bran defenders (and so many ableist anti-bran folks), that reading someone actually be...
question: Please, do rant away! There's so few Bran defenders (and so many ableist anti-bran folks), that reading someone actually be angry about his show and fandom treatment is such a welcome sight
answer:
Ah, I was sort of expecting hate mail lol. There’s not many aspects of that season that I’m not mad about. (Okay it’s basically down to forgesex, Theonsa, Dany getting to smile a bunch in 8x01, Jenny of Oldstones, Ser Brienne, and uh yeah that’s it) Bran being forced to be and then remain an emotionless shell who’s handed the south because he has the ultimate virtue of not wanting anything and then gets called by his depression nickname instead of a more appropriate and positive name ex “The Winged Wolf”, then handing his actual rightful claim to the north to Sansa, ignoring all the political reasons that’s stupid, is like getting a beating. Each thing is a successive slap in the face and that’s not even getting into the number of tired and frankly illogical (and ableist and horrifically sexist) fantasy tropes that came into play in that season. Bran deserved so much better and his being all “zen” and “ruling” the south is not my idea of a happy or “bittersweet” ending. (being a huge sucker for actual bittersweet endings I can tell y’all that there wasn’t an ounce of bittersweet in s8. It was just on a scale from gut-wrenching pointless tragedy, enraging, stupid, illogical, and contrived).

I can’t even get into how much of the fandom treats him from erasing his identity, pretending that magic is his consolation prize for his disability/ that he “couldn’t have become the 3ER without being disabled” (which is horseshit), embracing the show’s treatment of him, often because it gives a certain character a stronger claim to WF, trying to justify the use of that ableist moniker because it was a “shout-out” to the books as if context and sensitivity shouldn’t come into play, especially when he has another moniker that isn’t insulting and several potential names that are positive. Also, a ruler doesn’t have to be given a moniker at the beginning of their reign. Sure Aslan can call the Pevensies “The Magnificent” and “The Valiant” because he’s furry Jesus but irl and ITB monikers usually come after some accomplishment and can change because of events. 

There’s just so much awful stuff out there and a lot of it is directed towards characters that are disabled (Bran mostly but also minor characters like Lollys or Doran) or gender non-conforming (Brienne, Arya, Meera, Ygritte, Asha/Yara, Osha, Loras - because many LGBT+ people don’t conform to gender norms) [sidenote: I’ve seen too many posts from Sansa stans focusing on how each GNC woman, mostly Brienne, Arya, and Meera, should be a guard and that’s a ‘happy’ ending for that woman; we’re ignoring my rant about show!Brienne’s ending], and at characters who break with gender norms but I’m not sure they’d be considered GNC (Dany, Bran again, Edmure - which leads to the examination of how a lot of the hate that’s directed at Edmure, connected to the show’s horrible treatment of him, has to do with his failing to measure up to the violent masculinity that’s expected). It really shows a lot about the biases of fans, of the writers and production crew (not to mention some of the things the actors have said but I don’t take anything they say seriously).

Bran deserved more focus and more screentime especially time in which he was allowed to express himself and have real conversations with people. He’s kind and sensitive and had big dreams that got crushed (friendly reminder that it was Bran whose dream was to be a knight while Arya wanted an administrative role such as king’s councilor) and he’s angry about it and all of that was just brushed over and eventually erased. They even ignored some of the horrible things he did - namely his treatment of Hodor and how at some point canon!Bran is either going to have to look at what he did to Hodor, using and treating him like an animal and learn and redeem himself from that. To D&D Bran wasn’t even a person, he was just erased into a plot information machine that only worked 30% of the time and then they handed him a kingdom because it would “subvert expectations”.

summary: The scene after Jon hushed Sansa in favor of Dany when Jon was ready to follow Dany but Arya stepped in front of him and said...
body: The scene after Jon hushed Sansa in favor of Dany when Jon was ready to follow Dany but Arya stepped in front of him and said that they needed a word and Jon just looked at Sansa and Bran standing nearby. Epic

tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
title: Going North
body:
Chapter 1 of my Game of Thrones story is officially done! I have the rest written already and will be updating every other day. Read the first chapter here.

Summary:

Bran falls and wakes with visions in his mind, unknowing of a path that will now go untraveled. Together with his brother Jon, he must go north in search of the Raven and the salvation it promises.

summary: Dorne starting an uprising would not benefit them. Bran still has his powers so he would see it and although he has no army the...
question: Dorne starting an uprising would not benefit them. Bran still has his powers so he would see it and although he has no army the other Kingdoms except for the Iron Islands would not join and would just form an army to fight back and their numbers would overwhelm Dorne and the Iron Islands. Plus Sansa would probably support her brother as an ally ans send some men. Also like you said Dorne has not been interested in independence and it already functions semi-autonomously anyway.
answer: Bran wouldn’t. That’s my point, he was chosen despite not having Targaryen and Baratheon blood. If Dorne wants independence, they should send a raven and honestly Bran would already know and probably doesn’t care. The deal Dorne made with Daeron II is still in place so they have their laws and pay less in taxes than the other kingdoms

summary: is isaac in Romania right now or something?
question: is isaac in Romania right now or something?
answer:
Yes, he’s in Bucharest, Romania because he’s going to film his new movie “Voyagers”. He’s with some cast mates like Archie Renaux, Lily-Rose Depp, Archie Madekwe, Fionn Whitehead and Quintessa Q Swindell. (You can see them all in the photo)

The director of the movie is Neil Burger and he posted on Instagram some photos of the set months ago and it is in Bucharest so I guess the filming will start soon. I read that it will start in June 17th so we’ll probably have more information by that date.

tags: you know people aren't sincere when targ stans are the ones making these posts
as always these posts aren't directed to genuine dornish fans lmao i reblog 'dorne will be independent' posts from them
summary: after weeks of reading how the dornish were just as bad as the genocidal targaryens for fighting back, i have to say i’m glad...
body:
after weeks of reading how the dornish were just as bad as the genocidal targaryens for fighting back, i have to say i’m glad that the fandom suddenly matured and decided that dorne really really needs its independence, in fact it especially needs it more than the north. as we all know in doran’s to do list the word independence was very big and underlined several times. elia’s murder isn’t the motivation in the dorne subplot, it’s independence. doran was planning on making viserys and then daenerys the rulers of westeros by marrying them to his children as a roundabout way of getting independence. 

this sudden support for dornish self determination from non dornish fans is in no way connected to the fact that bran is king and sansa is queen. this fandom has never been racist while talking about the martells, it’s always been inclusive of martell fans. there are no theories about the water gardens burning because doran didn’t know his place, nope none of that happened. we all know that the dornish characters were treated by d&d got a big sustained backlash from the fandom. so on and so forth

reblog.comment:

trail.content_raw:
after weeks of reading how the dornish were just as bad as the genocidal targaryens for fighting back, i have to say i’m glad that the fandom suddenly matured and decided that dorne really really needs its independence, in fact it especially needs it more than the north. as we all know in doran’s to do list the word independence was very big and underlined several times. elia’s murder isn’t the motivation in the dorne subplot, it’s independence. doran was planning on making viserys and then daenerys the rulers of westeros by marrying them to his children as a roundabout way of getting independence. 

this sudden support for dornish self determination from non dornish fans is in no way connected to the fact that bran is king and sansa is queen. this fandom has never been racist while talking about the martells, it’s always been inclusive of martell fans. there are no theories about the water gardens burning because doran didn’t know his place, nope none of that happened. we all know that the dornish characters were treated by d&d got a big sustained backlash from the fandom. so on and so forth
trail.content:
after weeks of reading how the dornish were just as bad as the genocidal targaryens for fighting back, i have to say i’m glad that the fandom suddenly matured and decided that dorne really really needs its independence, in fact it especially needs it more than the north. as we all know in doran’s to do list the word independence was very big and underlined several times. elia’s murder isn’t the motivation in the dorne subplot, it’s independence. doran was planning on making viserys and then daenerys the rulers of westeros by marrying them to his children as a roundabout way of getting independence. 

this sudden support for dornish self determination from non dornish fans is in no way connected to the fact that bran is king and sansa is queen. this fandom has never been racist while talking about the martells, it’s always been inclusive of martell fans. there are no theories about the water gardens burning because doran didn’t know his place, nope none of that happened. we all know that the dornish characters were treated by d&d got a big sustained backlash from the fandom. so on and so forth

blog.name: madaboutasoiaf
blog.title: Fear cuts deeper than swords
blog.description: Jo, Female, Australian, This is an ASOIAF blog. Not a spoiler free zone

summary: I’ve started rereading AGOT in my minimal spare time and this bit gets me every single time “Lord Stark,” Jon said. It was...
body:
I’ve started rereading AGOT in my minimal spare time and this bit gets me every single time

“Lord Stark,” Jon said. It was strange to hear him call Father that, so formal. Bran looked at him with desperate hope. “There are five pups,” he told Father. “Three male, two female.”
“What of it, Jon?”
“You have five trueborn children,” Jon said. “Three sons, two daughters. The direwolf is the sigil of your House. Your children were meant to have these pups, my lord.”
Bran saw his father’s face change, saw the other men exchange glances. He loved Jon with all his heart at that moment. Even at seven, Bran understood what his brother had done. The count had come right only because Jon had omitted himself. He had included the girls, included even Rickon, the baby, but not the bastard who bore the surname Snow, the name that custom decreed be given to all those in the north unlucky enough to be born with no name of their own.
Their father understood as well. “You want no pup for yourself, Jon?” he asked softly.
“The direwolf graces the banners of House Stark,” Jon pointed out. “I am no Stark, Father.”

The emotions

summary: so the actor who played the unnamed prince of dorne said that his character would probably organise a dornish uprising. but why?...
body: so the actor who played the unnamed prince of dorne said that his character would probably organise a dornish uprising. but why? why not just tell bran that he wants independence? bran has no standing army and has given no indication he is forcing anyone under his rule esp since he was chosen. it makes no sense. if the audience hasn’t been hating on bran for no good reason, would that actor have said the same thing?

summary: yes yes ravens are creepy omens of death and the three eyed raven is all powerful and mysterious and creepy but did you know...
body:
yes yes ravens are creepy omens of death and the three eyed raven is all powerful and mysterious and creepy but did you know ravens are also like:

basically give me bran who looks all scary but he’s actually an absolute dork who talks too much and collects shiny things

tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
summary: After watching, I thought of something but it remains a theory: As we know, the children of the forest created the Night King to...
body:
After watching, I thought of something but it remains a theory:
As we know, the children of the forest created the Night King to defend themselves against the first men, but what if, in fact, it was the three-eyed raven who suggested the creation of the white walkers to the children of the forest? After all, the three eyed raven is very linked to the barrals, which the first men had begun to cut without distinction, and that, the raven wanted to avoid it, to not lose all its power. I’m not saying that this raven is necessarily the one we see before Bran in the series, but another before him. The bodies succeed one another, but the entity remains the same.
Unfortunately, the walkers escaped the control of their creators, as we know, and had to be repel into the lands of eternal winter, but that, the raven could have planned it too and remained patient.
Millennia later, with the return of the Night King and the appearance of a new potential “host” (Bran), the three-eyed raven having reincarnated  himself into several bodies over the millennia, would have seen a new opportunity, and would focus everyone’s attention on the Night King by describing him as the ultimate threat to stop, to dispel any suspicion about himself (and what better for that than to reincarnate in the body of a disabled young man). Bran, or rather the raven, said that the Night King wanted his death because he is the memory of this world, but you have to pay attention to what Old Nan said in the first season: “The crows are all liars.”
The Night King was certainly trying to kill the raven because he was the only strong enough to stop him but also the only one to know his true intentions, thanks to the power of visions he also had.
Like the others, the Night King has only been a puppet of the raven to serve his plans. What could be better as an ideal scapegoat than a necromancer king out of control and ready to ravage everything?
All this was a plan orchestrated by the three-eyed raven to become the king and thus regain control of his land, Westeros.
Once again, it remains a theory.
